headline_news_section: Aung San Suu Kyi knows how to win over a crowd.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: And not just in Myanmar. In 2012, Ireland was her first stop after she was presented with the Nobel Peace Prize in Norway - 19 years late.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: On her first visit to Europe in 25 years, she told an audience in Dublin that the British had always referred to the Burmese as the Irish of the East - she said they never quite understood why but it was possibly because they never gave the British any peace and were very rebellious.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: As she stood in the Bord Gáis Theatre, a year after she was freed from house arrest, she'd just been elected to Myanmar’s Parliament.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: Aung San Suu Kyi during her visit to Dublin in 2012

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: Her National League for Democracy had taken 43 of 45 seats in a series of byelections - a success it would repeat in the country’s first "free and fair" elections in 2015 and which made her Myanmar’s de facto leader.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: But Suu Kyi’s story is nothing, if not complicated.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: Her father, Aung San, founded the modern Burmese army and negotiated Burma’s independence from Britain in 1947. He was assassinated shortly after. In 1989, the army he founded arrested his daughter and put her under house arrest.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: A global human rights icon for decades, Suu Kyi was in Dublin to receive Amnesty International’s 'Ambassador of Conscience Award'. But just six years later, Amnesty would strip her of the honour, accusing her of a "shameful betrayal of values" for her treatment of Myanmar’s Rohingya minority.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: Six months before her trip to Dublin, I’d stood in the garden of her lakeside villa in Yangon as she prepared her first run for public office.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: A far cry from the days when people risked arrest, just for listening

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: As Myanmar’s 'democratic spring’ began to bloom, I’d gone to talk to the country’s military junta about opening a BBC bureau there. 54 million people live there - and millions get their news from BBC Burmese.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: In recent years, the media has been liberalised. Until today, several BBC programmes were shown on local stations in Myanmar - a far cry from the days when people risked arrest, just for listening.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: On that January day, thousands lined the streets, braving the baking sun, just to get a glimpse of the woman Burmese people call 'The Lady'.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: After months of delicate negotiations with the junta, the military leaders had agreed to a transition of power - and Aung San Suu Kyi was going to contest a seat in Myanmar’s lower House of Parliament.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: It wasn’t her first election. When Suu Kyi returned to Burma after a long period living in Britain in 1988, the country’s longtime military leader stepped down.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: Pro-democracy demonstrations were violently suppressed by the army - and Suu Kyi addressed an estimated crowd of 500,000 people, demanding democratic government.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: Eventually, the military agreed to hold elections in which her National League for Democracy won 59% of the votes. The military annulled the election result, and instead of becoming Prime Minister, Suu Kyi was placed under house arrest.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: As we drove to the election office, where Suu Kyi would hand in her nomination papers, the eyes of the world were on a woman about to reach her destiny.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: Aung San Suu Kyi signs her election papers

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: Dozens of her supporters packed into the small, drab District Election Commission office in Yangon’s Thanlyan township. They erupted in applause as she took her seat to formally register for the 1 April by-election, sitting directly opposite a representative of a regime that had jailed her and made her famous around the world.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: She won that election by a landslide, becoming opposition leader. And soon after, announced that she would run for the presidency in elections in 2015. Her National League For Democracy won a sweeping victory.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: But the army had one last card to play. In 2008, it introduced a new constitution for Myanmar - with one special clause. It banned anyone who was the widow and mother of foreigners from becoming President.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: In 1972, Suu Kyi had married the British historian Michael Aris, and her two sons had been born there. That prevented her from becoming President. It didn’t stop her from becoming Myanmar’s de facto ruler as Special Counsellor and Foreign Minister. Until today.

headline_name: Aung San Suu Kyi's 'complicated' democratic journey
headline_news_section: The democratic journey that began at her lakeside villa has ended as before - with Suu Kyi detained and Myanmar’s military back firmly in control.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section: Last year, Wexford GAA Manager Davy Fitzgerald filmed a new TV show where he met seven young men, all aged between 18 and 22, who have found themselves at a crossroads of an uncertain future.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section: Grappling with issues like drug addiction, isolation, homelessness, unemployment and mental health challenges, not to mention the COVID restrictions that came into place while filming, the prolific sports manager is on a mission to inspire these men to realise their dreams.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section: Renowned for his passion, drive and ability to bring teams back from the brink, Davy is determined to overcome every obstacle put in his way, to get this group of young men to achieve an adventure beyond their wildest dreams.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section: We caught up with the coach to find out more about the show and what he plans to do next.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section:
How did the concept of the show come about?
Myself and Animo - the production company - would sit down at the end of every year and look at different projects. We came up with this one based on the fact that I went to Everest Base Camp in 2012 and I explained what an experience it was and how it helped me. It made me understand more about the world and the way people live and how things can be a lot simpler. We started looking at the struggles that the age group of 18-22 go through and I'm delighted we had that conversation.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section:
What skills did you bring from GAA and Fittest Family to a show like this?
My management style in the GAA has changed a lot in the last few years. I focus on understanding the individuals - their mannerisms and what makes them tick. When you have a group of people, you can't treat them all the same way because they're not the same. I have to figure out what will motivate each person and how to get the best out of them. Bringing that [perspective], as well as bringing people in to help me, would give these guys a step up. I have to make it clear though: You can do everything but it's up to the guys. If they don't want to take that step, it's not going to happen.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section: Daniel Phipps

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section:
Was it harder to get these young men to trust you given how much they had been through?
It was tough. These guys have probably been let down with different things and they find it hard to trust people so you had to build that trust up. It was very challenging to get the guys to buy in but it was very rewarding once they did.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section:
Were there any surprises along the way?
Believe it or not, and a lot of people would find this hard to believe, but I'm very soft at heart. When I heard some of their stories, I'll be honest, it got to me. Seeing where they were at times and the troubles they were going through... it really got to me. I so just wanted to fix it and make it better but I wasn't capable of that. I can't just do that, they have to want to do it. This was a way for them to get a small bit of help and, hopefully, they can build on that and things will get easier.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section: Cian O'Mahony

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section:
Why did you think a physical challenge would be helpful to them?
We did all sorts of challenges - physical and mental - and what that does is tell you someone's behavioural pattern. Do they trust someone else? How do they react under pressure? Their reactions gave me an idea of their profile and that gave me an idea of how we could help them progress. We could talk through things and make them think about things before they react.

headline_name: Davy Fitzgerald on mentoring young men and being "soft at heart"
headline_news_section:

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: Analysis: it is more than timely that an independent group examines Ireland's Defence Forces, although its remit is not to delve too deeply

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: Buried amidst the ongoing Covid-19 crisis, the Cabinet quietly agreed on December 15th to establish an independent commission on the Defence Forces. This completes a promise from the June programme for government and comes at a time when the role of the Defence Forces in mobilising against the pandemic has been hugely appreciated.

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: Yet fighting diseases is not the essence of what armies, navies and airforces do. Their job is to defend any state from violent actors, whether other states or non-state groups. For Ireland's Defence Forces, this essential role is often loss sight of given their abilities as peacekeepers overseas or their support for An Garda Siochána at home. The Irish Defence Forces have sometimes been viewed as a residual type of state labour force. In fact, they're a highly professional military struggling to cope with years of neglect and a defence spend which in comparative terms is among the lowest in Europe.

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: From RTÉ Radio 1's Drivetime, Brigadier General Brendan McGuinness on the role of the defence forces in fighting Covid

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: It is more than timely that an expert group examines Ireland's Defence Forces, although the remit of the group is not to delve too deeply. The programme for government in June 2020 made it clear that any commission would not critically examine Ireland’s ambiguous policy of non-membership of military alliances or neutrality so that is firmly off the table for discussion by the group. Instead, the commission will "take account of Ireland’s particular defence requirements, including its strong international commitment in the overseas domain as well as the particular roles of the Defence Forces in the domestic security environment which itself continues to evolve."

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: Removing the political hot potato of neutrality may permit the Commission to deal with many other issues in greater substance. There will be no shortage of these! They include an Irish military that is now tiny and struggling to fill units and missions; recruitment and retention problems; endemic complaints about pay and conditions and especially the process for the determination of these; and a reserve force that is barely functioning with abysmally low numbers.

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: By international standards, the levels of equipment and modernisation of the Irish Defence Forces are below international norms. The Irish air corps have no radar system to monitor Irish airspace and no fast aircraft to police it (for example, both Finland and Uruguay do). The Irish navy have no guided missiles, torpedoes or more importantly, sophisticated ship protection systems, but instead are austerely equipped as a coastguard. The Irish army have no tanks, a small number of lightly armed and protected vehicles, and an ageing collection of artillery pieces. Unlike other modern militaries, dedicated cyber and electronic warfare units have not been created, although some capabilities do exist for this.

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: From RTÉ Radio 1's Morning Ireland, Conor King from the Representative Association of Commissioned Officers (RACO), on the newly announced independent review of the Defence Forces

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: It will be fascinating to see what observations the very senior foreign military experts on the Commission will make, as they come from Norway’s Navy and Finland’s army respectively. While they will be familiar with Irish military professionals, they may be in for a shock at how limited the basic Irish Defence Force is compared with their own home countries.

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: The committee will likely encounter the usual objections here that Ireland cannot afford modern war material or that we do not need it. In fact, militaries require a range of capabilities and it is dangerous to provide them with only the bare minimum for day to day operations or lower order threats. Any defence force needs capabilities for future contingencies and the ability to evolve in facing what may well be extreme events requiring a fuller spectrum of force to be employed. Moroever, in per capita income terms, Ireland is at least as well off as Finland, New Zealand or Austria and yet Ireland’s military balance sheet appears much more limited than those countries. Plainly speaking, Ireland’s Defence Forces have been allowed decline when compared with improvements in other small states. Will the Commission address this?

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: From RTÉ Radio 1's News At One, interview with Vice Admiral Mark Mellett, Chief of Staff of the Defence Forces

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: They can certainly probe and explore such issues, and the terms of reference suggest (in civil service speak) that the Committee "will have regard to the level of funding provided by Government for Defence". Yet the core limitation of any commission remains that it is only as good as its recommendations are acted upon. Ireland has a long history of very worthy independent reports gathering dust. While the Commission will report within 12 months, real change may be longer in coming, especially if legislative change of the Defence Acts is required, as that usually proceeds glacially.

headline_name: Can a new Defence Forces' commission reboot Ireland's military?
headline_news_section: Luckily, there is strong leadership evident from the current Minister responsible, Simon Coveney and the existing Chief of Staff, Vice Admiral Mark Mellet. It is just possible that a window of opportunity exists to reboot Ireland defence forces or at the very least, to redress some of the problems arising from years of neglect.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: "I know a man who gave up smoking, drinking, sex and rich food. He was healthy right up to the day he killed himself." This quote from the television host and comedian Johnny Carson illustrates an uncomfortable truth – that we can't always be angels. And nor should we be.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Research has uncovered a variety of benefits that can arise from instances of what might otherwise label as "bad" behaviour.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Swearing

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: There are many well documented benefits of swearing, including improving pain tolerance, boosting physical strength and helping social cohesion. And the studies keep on coming. A recent one found that swearing can be an effective coping strategy for dealing with road rage. Hundreds of drivers were shown images depicting three rage-inducing driving scenarios: being slowed by pedestrians crossing against the lights, being "cut up" by another driver who fails to acknowledge right of way and an illegally stopped car blocking the way ahead.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Half were instructed to swear, out loud or quietly, while the other half were asked to be silent. After swearing, drivers reported feeling more positive, suggesting that swearing can ease road rage. And surely it is better to swear in the car for a few minutes than to get to your destination and behave badly towards the people around you? There are many reasons why swearing – a cheap, readily available, calorie-neutral, drug-free means of self-help – is number one on this list.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Drinking

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: It is widely accepted now that there is no safe limit for drinking alcohol, indicating that alcohol is firmly "bad". Yet, it remains popular and, at moderate levels, potentially useful. Take this recent study finding that alcohol can make you a more fluent speaker of a foreign language. Researchers gave vodka and bitter lemon drinks, with alcohol content equivalent to one to two bottles of beer, to some German students living and studying at a Dutch university.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Ever heard that only boring people get bored? It's a popular belief in the busy and goal-oriented times we live in, which can make us look down on people who are bored as lazy or unimaginative. But is that the case? Amazingly, boredom is a universal human experience – everyone finds themselves bored from time to time. Psychologists say it is simply a feeling of having no intention or purpose – an unsuccessful desire to engage in the world. It's rather like being in limbo.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Embrace boredom sometimes. mimagephotography/Shutterstock

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: But what's the point of feeling like this? One answer is that boredom compels us to try and establish meaning, which can trigger creativity. One study has shown that deliberately making people bored by watching dull videos (for example someone hanging out laundry) produces measurably improved performance of subsequent creativity tasks. So, actually, boredom may be a state to be embraced as a condition of possibility and opportunity.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Being stupid

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Believe it or not, there may be an upside to being stupid – or at least being willing to embrace how stupid feels. Writing in the Journal of Cell Science, microbiologist Martin Schwartze tells a story about meeting up with an old acquaintance, one of the brightest people he had met, who abandoned her scientific training to become a lawyer. She told him she'd given up science because it made her feel stupid.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: This shocking statement echoed in his thoughts until the next day, when it suddenly occurred to him – doing science made him feel stupid too. It can often be unclear whether you are even asking the right questions, let alone finding the right answers. Schwartze realised that not having all the answers forces us to confront our "absolute stupidity". If you can accept this feeling, it can become liberating, helping you muddle through and tolerate mistakes along the way – buoyed by the possibility of amazing discoveries.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: This is also true outside of science. It can be motivating to challenge or even doubt yourself from time to time. Research shows that most of us are in fact over-confident in our abilities, which can get in the way of the learning and developing that makes us smarter in the long run.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Making social transgressions

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Perhaps the ultimate kind of bad behaviour is social transgression. Killing another person is, of course, very harmful bad behaviour. But what about more mundane acts of rebellion? I've often thought that a little social transgression is necessary to break free of a potentially endless cycle of etiquette and politeness.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: There is something to be said for low-level social transgression as a tool for prompting some genuine human warmth and interaction

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: In a wonderful study, researchers dared hundreds of undergraduate students to go into the world, break a minor social norm and record the consequences. One ran up a downward escalator in a shopping centre. Another lowered their car windows and sang loudly. Another sat next to an old lady on an otherwise empty bus.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: The escalator prank did not go down well, drawing glares of disapproval. But passersby cheered and joined in with the automotive singing, and the old lady welcomed the opportunity to chat. Overall, when all examples were logged and categorised, only a minority of the transgressions were negatively received (35.4%). There is something to be said for low-level social transgression as a tool for breaking free of convention and prompting some genuine human warmth and interaction.

headline_name: Why swearing, drinking, and being stupid are good for you
headline_news_section: Richard Stephens is a Senior Lecturer in Psychology at Keele University. This piece was originally published by The Conversation.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: When is Chinese New Year?

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: Chinese New Year, also known as the Spring Festival, is the most important festival in China and in several countries of East Asia. It has gradually become a global festival in recent years with its cultural connotations of joy, harmony, sharing and blessing. In Chinese culture, it is believed that spring is a new start, bringing people hope and renewal.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: Chinese Lunar Year begins at sunset on the day of the second New Moon following the winter solstice (21st December). This means the New Year can begin anytime from January 21st through to February 21st.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: The first day of the coming lunar New Year falls on 12th February, 2021.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: Chinese New Year - Animal Signs

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: Each year in the Chinese calendar is represented by one of twelve animals in the Chinese Zodiac. 2021 will be the year of the Ox.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: The Ox is second of the 12 animal signs of the Chinese zodiac, with the nature of great patience and a desire to make progress, the Ox symbolizes diligence and determination.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section:
Workers hang colourful lanterns at a park to mark the upcoming Chinese New Year,
the Year of the Ox, on January 30, 2021 in Yuncheng, Shanxi Province of China.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: Traditions of Chinese New Year

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: The Chinese New Year is very similar to the Western one, swathed in traditions and rituals.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: The origin of the Chinese New Year is itself ancient and obscured by the amount of time. The celebrations usually last 15 days and the public holiday is about a week long. In China alone, the Spring Festival is the biggest human migration in the world as over 400 million people empty the cities and return to their rural homes across the country (with exceptions during the ongoing pandemic).

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: Preparations begin a month before, with New Year's Eve perhaps the most exciting part of the event, as anticipation creeps in. Here, traditions and rituals are very carefully observed in everything from food to clothing. Key rituals include cleaning the house, putting up new posters of "door gods" on front doors, the family union dinner of many courses symbolizing the abundance of the coming year.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: Red decorations are everywhere, and it's usual to wear something red as this colour is meant to ward off evil spirits. Fireworks used to be a huge part of Chinese New Year celebrations, but many cities in China have now restricted fireworks due to safety concerns and air cleaning.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: The tradition comes from a folk tale about a monster named Nian who was scared away using firecrackers.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: In Chinese, the common greeting at New Year is "xin nian kuai le", which means "Happy New Year". Those in Hong Kong area and other Cantonese-speaking parts of the world tend to go with "gong hei fat choy" which translates roughly to "congratulations on your good fortune".

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: The customs of Hong Bao, meaning 'money in red envelopes', giving to relatives and friends, and New Year Greetings have embraced modern technology through social media platforms such as WeChat in recent years. Attracting more than 1.2 billion viewers, CCTV's Spring Festival Gala is the most-watched national network TV broadcast in the world.

headline_name: Chinese New Year - everything you need to know
headline_news_section: The end of the New Year is marked by the Festival of Lanterns, on the next full moon, which is a celebration with singing, dancing, and lantern shows.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: Jonjoe Kenny insists his Celtic move has been perfectly timed after agreeing a six-month loan switch from Everton.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: It has been a miserable season for the Hoops, with their Premiership 10-in-a-row dreams lying in tatters.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: But Toffees right-back Kenny is excited about the possibilities in store in Glasgow.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: The 23-year-old former England Under-21 defender - who goes straight into Neil Lennon's squad for Thursday's clash with Kilmarnock at Rugby Park - told CelticTV: "The stature of the club and how big it is made it a decision I couldn't turn down.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "To come up here and play my football at a club like this is perfect for me right now.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "I want to come here and help the club first of all, and help the lads.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "Obviously, it's been a bit difficult, but I just want to come here and try my best and give my all to Celtic, get out there and play and get some games for me, to show people what I can do and show my qualities.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "First of all, I enjoy playing football. I like getting the ball, playing nice football and getting forward and putting crosses in, but on the other side of that, I feel that I am aggressive, I like making tackles and just giving my all."

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: Kenny came through the Everton ranks under the guidance of former Rangers hitman Duncan Ferguson.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: He has registered 48 run-outs for the Goodison Park outfit, while he spent last season in Germany with Bundesliga side Schalke.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: He will now fill the slot left by Jeremie Frimpong, who quit Celtic Park for Bayer Leverkusen last week.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "I know what's coming ahead of me, what challenges I've got and that's why I've come here," added Kenny. "I want to challenge myself and see how far I can take myself too.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "Going to Germany was a completely different experience - a different way of life, learning a new language and basically becoming like a German person, and it was just great.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "It's another string to my bow, and all these experiences will come in handy now that I've joined Celtic.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "There's a lot of history in the air and a lot of top players have come and gone from here, so it was the first day and it was just good to be involved and train with the lads.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "The lads were brilliant - people from Glasgow are similar to Scousers - so it's been brilliant for me to come in and settle in quickly.

headline_name: Celtic complete loan move for Everton's Jonjoe Kenny
headline_news_section: "I want to be involved straight away and we'll see what happens. I'm just made up to be here and we'll see what happens tomorrow, but the quicker I can play, the better it'll be for me."

headline_name: Warning over sale of fake Covid-19 travel documents
headline_news_section: Europol has warned that fake negative Covid-19 test certificates and documentation are being sold to people, enabling them to avoid travel restrictions, and have identified an Irish criminal gang as allegedly being involved.

headline_name: Warning over sale of fake Covid-19 travel documents
headline_news_section: The European law enforcement agency said it received intelligence on the alleged use of a mobile application by a crime gang based in the south of the country, which allows for the manual falsification of test results.

headline_name: Warning over sale of fake Covid-19 travel documents
headline_news_section: It has said several cases of such fraudulent certificates being sold to travellers have already emerged.

headline_name: Warning over sale of fake Covid-19 travel documents
headline_news_section: It cites a forgery ring at Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris, which was dismantled after having sold negative test results.

headline_name: Warning over sale of fake Covid-19 travel documents
headline_news_section: In the UK, fraudsters were also caught selling bogus Covid-19 documents for more than £100 each.

headline_name: Warning over sale of fake Covid-19 travel documents
headline_news_section: In December of last year, one fraudster was also caught by police in Spain, for selling fake test results for €40 each.

headline_name: Warning over sale of fake Covid-19 travel documents
headline_news_section: Europol warns that as long as travel restrictions remain in place due to the pandemic, it is "very likely" that criminals will seize the opportunity of producing and selling fake Covid-19 test certificates.

headline_name: Warning over sale of fake Covid-19 travel documents
headline_news_section: Given the widespread technological means available, in the form of high-quality printers and different software, the agency said that fraudsters are able to produce "high-quality counterfeit, forged or fake documents".

headline_name: Warning over sale of fake Covid-19 travel documents
headline_news_section: It is encouraging EU member states to share any relevant information on criminal activities related to fake Covid-19 test documentation with them.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: In Irish folk tradition, the calendar is principally split into 'Quarter Days', so called as they divide the year into each of its four seasons of summer (May Day / Bealtaine), autumn (Lammas / Lúnasa), winter (Halloween / Samhain) and, of course, spring (St. Brigid’s Day / Imbolc), which falls on the 1st of February. Jonny Dillon, folklorist, tells us of her cultural significance.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: St. Brigid’s Day is dedicated to the saint nicknamed Muire na nGael or the ‘Mary of the Irish’, a designation given to her on account of the adoration and high regard in which she has long been held by the people of this island. The special position attributed to her is reflected even in the name Brigid, which means ‘high’, ‘lofty’, ‘elevated’, or ‘exalted’ one.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: To come to a full understanding and appreciation of her feast however, we must examine the Pre-Christian roots, not just of the celebration, but of the figure of Brigid herself.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: Prior to any veneration of the early Christian saint, the 1st of February was the day on which the festival of Imbolc was held in Ireland; a festival which, in welcoming the arrival of spring, had as its focus fertility and propagation. The word Imbolc literally means ‘in the womb’, though it also appears in early literature as Oímelc meaning ‘lactation’; both words however, attest to a consideration at this time of birth, renewal and the feminine.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: Attached to the celebration of Imbolc was the Pre-Christian deity Brighid, patroness of poets, smith workers and livestock, goddess of healing and daughter of the Daghda (who himself was father-god of the Tuatha Dé Danann; the mythical race said to inhabit Ireland before the arrival of humans).

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: The festival of Imbolc, dedicated as it is to the goddess Brighid and falling as it does on the 1st of February, would seem later to have become heavily associated with the woman who, born in Co. Louth around 455 AD, Christianised her tribe, took the name of Brigid, and went on to establish what is likely Ireland’s oldest monastery at Kildare (a demonstration of the central role of women at the earliest phase of the Christian church in Ireland).

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: The most widely known custom connected with St. Brigid’s Day involves the construction of rushwork crosses. These crosses are most likely Pre-Christian in origin and appear in a variety of types; most familiar perhaps is the four-armed, swastika type cross, although there are also three armed crosses and elaborate lozenge type crosses found in other portions of the country.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: These crosses, hung in the rafters of the house, were employed to garner the blessing of the saint and to protect the home against fire. The cross making tradition was quite weak in Leinster, and would seem to have been almost entirely unknown in Co. Wicklow (although there is small evidence for the construction of crosses in the area around Lough Dan in the centre of the county).

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: More widely observed across Ireland, was the practice of dressing up the dash of a churn (a once common household item used by our forebears in the production of butter) as an effigy of the saint. This effigy was called the Brídeog.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: The Brídeog having been constructed, a band of young men would travel the locality from house to house masked in ‘vizards’ so as to be rendered anonymous, and, wearing ‘strange clothes’ and women’s garments, this motley assortment (known as ‘Biddy Boys’) would play mouth organs, melodeons, and concertinas in each of the houses they visited.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: Upon entering the house the Biddy Boys would begin their music, singing and dancing, and the leader of the procession, brandishing the effigy of the saint, would entreat the occupants therein to hand over a few pence in order that St. Brigid might bless and protect them in the year ahead. The money gathered by the Biddy Boys was thereafter used in organising a dance in the locality (or, as was described in one instance, put to good use in an altogether more private capacity at a local public house!)

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: St. Brigid herself was said to travel across Ireland on the eve of her feast, and items were often left outside the house overnight so as to procure her blessing. In the land around Lower Calary in north east Wicklow, a dish of salt was kept outside on the eve of the 1st of February, this was then used to cure sore throats. In other parts of the country a ribbon or piece of fabric was left out overnight. This was known as ‘Brigid’s Mantle’, and was used to ensure fertility in women and assist them in childbirth.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: St. Brigid’s curative powers are further recognisable in lore regarding holy wells in Wicklow that bear her name. Lower Calary in north east Wicklow has two holy wells dedicated to St. Brigid, the water from one of which was renowned to have a cure for vomiting. In Rathdangan in west Wicklow individuals with warts would visit their local St. Brigid’s well nine days in succession, bathing the affected area in order to rid themselves of their ailment. Similar practices were carried out at St. Brigid’s well in Kilranelagh, in west Wicklow, and small items and relics were left at this well in honour of the saint; a ribbon or a ‘holy picture’, we are told.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: Symbols of fertility, rebirth and femininity resonate through Brigid, and with spring come the gifts of propagation, renewal and growth. There is a promise in the air: soil is yet to be tilled and our young yet to be born, but the harsh rigours of winter are passing away.

headline_name: St. Brigid's powerful cultural heritage
headline_news_section: Brigid, spring, you are welcome, come in!

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: Jamie McGrath says there's a great buzz around St Mirren after they earned a first league win over Celtic at Parkhead in 31 years at the weekend.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: First-half goals from Kristian Dennis and IlKay Durmus were enough to see the Paisley club triumph at the home of the champions and pile more pressure on Hoops manager Neil Lennon.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: Speaking on RTÉ's Game On, Meath man McGrath said it was an occasion to savour.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "We're still on a high," he admitted. "To go to Celtic Park and take all three points is something the club hasn't done in a very long time.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "It was a great weekend. Quick turnaround, we've a busy schedule ahead. We've to get our heads fixed for Hibs tomorrow.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "We couldn't really enjoy it as much as we wanted but it was an amazing day.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "They've top international players all over the pitch. They're full of quality and they can hurt you - it only takes a second for them to do that so you have to be switched on at all times.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "We knew it was maybe a good time to catch Celtic. They haven't been playing at what they've been capable of doing for the last few years.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "We had belief. We went in and matched them up, man for man. We got the result that we probably didn't believe we would get, but it was some day."

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: The result moved The Buddies past Dundee United and into sixth position in the Scottish Premiership table.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: After three campaigns in the Championship in the last decade, the the club has continued to move in the right direction, finishing ninth in the top flight last season, up two places from the year before.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: There's a strong Irish contingent at the club, with Conor McCarthy, Dylan Connolly, Jake Doyle-Hayes, Sam Foley, as well as Oughterard's Joe Shaughnessy, the captain.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: The side is also managed by Tramore man Jim Goodwin, who won a cap for the Republic of Ireland back in 2002.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "It's a nice place to be at the minute," McGrath continued. "You've five Irish players, and then the gaffer is a Waterford man. There's a good contingent of Irish lads there, which helps.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "Obviously you don't want any cliques getting into the dressing room. That's not the way it is at all, it's a great dressing room to be a part of.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "At the minute we're in the top six and we're aiming to finish there. It's something the club has never done [before] so it's a great group of players."

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: McGrath freely admits that there was interest from English clubs when he was deciding where to go next after Dundalk, but said the lure of regular football was key.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: McGrath (l) moved to Scotland in January 2020

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: The 24-year-old has played 30 games since his move to Glasgow in January of last year, managing five goals in that time.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "I've started every game this year which is a great achievement so far," he acknowledged.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "Touch wood I can stay injury free. The team is playing some nice football at the minute. We're good to watch.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "As a player that's the team you want to play in a team that plays out from the back. It's great to be part of at the minute and we're going to strive for the top six.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "I think that was the general view when I moved," he said when asked about there being surprise in some quarters around the fact that he was moving from the Irish champions to a team that was then struggling to avoid Scottish Premiership relegation.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "I knew that this was needed, that it was best for me in my development. I could have gone to a team down south where I wasn't guaranteed game time.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "As part of my own development I thought this would be the best place to be. [The aim was to] try to play as many games as I could and luckily that's happened.

headline_name: McGrath: Move to Scotland key for my development
headline_news_section: "I've hit a good run of form as well, so looking back it's probably gone well so far. There's still a lot to do and a lot to achieve."

headline_name: Work to commence on next section of Liffey cycle route
headline_news_section: The Liffey Cycle Route has been delayed by the Covid-19 pandemic but work on the next section to Heuston Station will commence shortly, according to Dublin City Council.

headline_name: Work to commence on next section of Liffey cycle route
headline_news_section: An update to councillors revealed that works on St John's Road West/Victoria Quay junction will start soon allowing the rollout from Capel Street Bridge to Frank Sherwin Bridge at Heuston Station.

headline_name: Work to commence on next section of Liffey cycle route
headline_news_section: Designs for the section from O'Connell Bridge to Matt Talbot Bridge are also being finalised according to the report from Traffic Executive Manager Brendan O'Brien and Acting Chief Executive John W Flanagan.

headline_name: Work to commence on next section of Liffey cycle route
headline_news_section: Meanwhile the Green Party has welcomed the appointment of 55 extra staff to work on cycling and walking initiatives in Dublin city.

headline_name: Work to commence on next section of Liffey cycle route
headline_news_section: The new roles which include engineers and technical advisors are being funded through a sustainable mobility scheme announced by Minister for Transport and Green Party leader Eamon Ryan.

headline_name: Work to commence on next section of Liffey cycle route
headline_news_section: Green Party councillor Michael Pidgeon said: "Ten years ago I stood outside civic offices, campaigning for the council to hire just one cycling officer.

headline_name: Work to commence on next section of Liffey cycle route
headline_news_section: "A decade on and we're looking at hiring over 50 staff for active travel. This is the kind of practical change you see when you put Greens in local and national government," he said.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: Silver prices surged to a five-month high today, silver-mining stocks leapt and coin-selling websites were swamped as small-time investors scooped up the metal, the latest target of a retail-trading frenzy that has unnerved financial markets.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: Organised in online forums and traded with fee-free brokers, such as Robinhood, the phenomenon has driven a 1,500% rally in the shares of videogame retailer GameStop as the crowd targets assets big fund managers had bet against.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: The following are significant moments in the recent retail trading frenzy:

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: December 8, 2020 - GameStop shares tank after company misses Wall Street estimates for quarterly revenue as pandemic-led store closures and intense competition from digital-game sellers hit sales.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 11, 2021 - GameStop appoints Chewy.com founder and two other e-commerce veterans to its board in a deal with investor Ryan Cohen's RC Ventures, as it doubles down on digital sales.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 13 - GameStops shares rise 57%, followed by another 27% jump the next day to $39.90. Its median target price among analysts is only $12.50.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 19 - Short seller Citron Research takes aim. Tweets about GameStop, saying buyers at these levels are "the suckers at this poker game" and stock "back to $20 fast."

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 20 - Citron Research delays negative report, says it does not want to go live with its report on the stock.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 22 - Shares rise another 50%.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 25 - GameStop stock soars as much 144% then settles up 18% with retail traders storming in to buy more.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 26 - Elon Musk tweets "Gamestonk!!", along with a link to Reddit's Wallstreetbets stock trading discussion group, where supporters refer to the Tesla CEO as "Papa Musk."

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: Tesla CEO Elon Musk

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 27 - Melvin Capital and Citron closes the majority of their GameStop position at a loss.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 27 - US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell declined outright to comment on the extraordinary rise in the shares of an unprofitable company that seemed proof positive the market had become detached from reality.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 27 - A slugfest between Wall Street and Main Street took an unexpected turn after moderators of a stock trading forum that has helped fuel massive rallies in the shares of GameStop temporarily closed its doors.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 27 - Billionaire investor Steven Cohen's Point72 Asset Management has suffered a nearly 15% loss this year due to a sudden surge in the shares of video-game retailer GameStop, the New York Times reported.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 28 - The volume of bearish options bets on GameStop surged while bullish bets are taking a backseat after a run that has catapulted the video game and electronics retailer's shares more than 700% over the past four sessions.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 28 - Online trading platforms Robinhood and Interactive Brokers said they had restricted trading in shares of GameStop, BlackBerry and other companies that have seen hefty gains due to a social media-driven trading frenzy.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 29 - The chief executive of brokerage app Robinhood said he made a "difficult decision" to restrict buying in more than a dozen volatile stocks, including GameStop and AMC Entertainment, to protect the company and its customers.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 29 - Online brokerage Robinhood said it was not allowing purchases of parts of shares in GameStop and other stocks, a practice that has encouraged smaller investors by reducing the size of the amount they have to bet.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 29 - The US securities regulator said it would review actions that may "unduly inhibit" trading of certain securities and said it was closely monitoring potential wrongdoing amid recent price volatility in the US stock market.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 30 - Buyout firm Silver Lake disclosed that it sold its stake in AMC Entertainment Holdings for $713m this week, capitalising on a 10-fold rise in the price of the shares.

headline_name: Timeline - Silver surges as GameStop mania spills over
headline_news_section: January 31 - Melvin Capital, the hedge fund at the centre of the GameStop drama, lost 53% in January but received commitments for fresh cash from investors in the last days of the month, a source familiar with the fund said on Sunday.
